title: Is there a way to actually stage a build in /tmp (without the symlink)?
body:
I've been building the *shiny-server* package in a spack tree located at a convenient location (that happens to have a short path).

When I updated my Jenkins build to include *shiny-server*, the job failed while building *shiny-server* with this error (while cleaning up in part of the shiny server's built in node server):

```
make[4]: execvp: printf: Argument list too long
```

I scratched my head a bit and remembered that I had configured Spack to always stage "in-tree", like so:

```yaml
  # The build stage can be purged with `spack purge --stage`.
  build_stage:
    - $spack/var/spack/stage
```

It occurred to me that `/tmp` is a much shorter path than where Jenkins' workspace lives and so I changed it (back to) to this:

```yaml
  # The build stage can be purged with `spack purge --stage`.
  build_stage:
    - $tempdir
    - $spack/var/spack/stage
```

That build is running, but I noticed (and now remember) that Spack is still building in `.../var/spack/stage/yada/yada/yada` but that that is a link to `/tmp/username/spack-stage`.

I predict that when the job tries to build the shiny-server package it's going to blow up again.

**Is there any way to avoid the symlink and simply use the specified directory path?**
